question: Question_09
statement:
Consider the isosceles triangle given in the following figure, where
\emph{a} and \emph{b} indicate the side lengths. Assume that the
triangle has a circumference of 2. Find the lengths \emph{a} and
\emph{b} for which the area A of the triangle is maximized. You must
also check that you found a maximum and your solution must include that
check. \emph{Hint:} Heron's formula may be useful which states that

\[A^{2} = s(s - x)(s - y)(s - z)\] where \emph{A} is the area of the
triangle, \emph{x}, \emph{y}, \emph{z} are its side lengths and \emph{s
= (x+y+z)/2}.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH102_2011_9.png}
\end{description}
sols:
First, using Heron's formula, we have that the semiperimeter is
$\displaystyle s = 1$ and so

$\displaystyle A^{2} = (1-a)(1-a)(1-b)$.

Next, the perimeter is given by $\displaystyle 2 = 2a + b$ and so
$\displaystyle b = 2-a$. Substituting this into the area formula, we
have

$\displaystyle A^{2} = (1-a)^{2}(1-(2-2a)) = (1-a)^{2}(2a-1)$

Taking the derivative implicitly with respect to \emph{a} via the chain
rule and product rule, we have

\begin{align*}
 2AA' &= (2(1-a)(-1))(2a-1) + (1-a)^{2}(2) \\
&= -2(1-a)(2a-1) + 2(1-a)^{2} \\
&= 2(1-a)(-(2a-1) + (1-a)) \\
&= -2(1-a)(3a-2) 
\end{align*}

Setting the derivative to 0 and optimizing gives \emph{a}=1 and \emph{a}
= 2/3. Now, looking at the Perimeter restraint

$\displaystyle 2 = 2a + b$

We see that the maximum either occurs when \emph{a}=0, \emph{a}=1 (and
so \emph{b}=0, these last two values are the endpoints since side
lengths are non-negative) or when \emph{a}=2/3. At the first two values,
the area is 0 and so at \emph{a}=2/3 is where the maximum will be. Thus,

$\displaystyle A(2/3) = \sqrt{(1-(2/3))^{2}(2(2/3)-1)} = \sqrt{(1/9)(1/3)} = \frac{1}{3\sqrt{3}}$

completing the proof.
hints:
Try using the given hint in the problem to compute the area in terms of
the side lengths. Then use the given circumference (perimeter)
information to reduce the computation to one variable.
